full_conversation: Therapist: Alright, let's begin the imaginal exposure. Can you close your eyes and describe the memory of your relationship breakup?
Client: Okay... I'm sitting in our living room. The air feels heavy. My partner is across from me, looking... distant. I can feel my heart racing already.
Therapist: Good. What's your SUDS level right now?
Client: Um, probably around a 5 or 6.
Therapist: Okay. Continue describing what's happening.
Client: He's telling me it's over. His words are like knives. I feel... I feel like I can't breathe. The room is spinning. I want to scream, but no sound comes out.
Therapist: Stay with that feeling. What's happening in your body?
Client: My chest is so tight. My hands are shaking. I... I feel like I'm going to be sick.
Therapist: What's your SUDS now?
Client: It's... it's an 8. God, this feels awful.
Therapist: You're doing great. Keep going.

Client: I'm trying to understand why. Why now? After everything we've been through. I feel so betrayed, so... worthless. It's bringing up all these feelings from when I was a kid, you know? Like I'm not good enough, never have been.
Therapist: I hear you. What else do you notice?
Client: I'm... I'm crying now. In the memory, I mean. I can feel the tears on my face. My throat hurts from trying not to sob. I just want to disappear.
Therapist: SUDS level?
Client: Still an 8... maybe edging towards 9.
Therapist: It's okay to feel this. You're safe here.

Client: I watch him pack a bag. Each item he takes feels like he's tearing a piece of me away. I'm begging him to stay, to talk about it. But he's so cold, so distant. It's like I don't even know him anymore.
Therapist: What are you thinking in this moment?
Client: That I'll never be happy again. That I'm going to be alone forever. That maybe... maybe if I had been better, this wouldn't be happening.
Therapist: SUDS?
Client: It's... it's gone down a bit. Maybe a 7 now.
Therapist: That's good. Keep describing what's happening.

Client: He's at the door now. I'm on the floor, just... broken. I can't even stand. As he leaves, it's like all the air is sucked out of the room. I can't breathe. I'm gasping, crying. I feel so small, so insignificant.
Therapist: Stay with that feeling. What's your body doing?
Client: I'm curled up in a ball. My whole body is shaking. I feel nauseous, dizzy. Like the world is ending.
Therapist: And your SUDS now?
Client: It's... it's back up to an 8. This is so hard.
Therapist: You're doing incredibly well. Keep going.
Client: I don't know how long I stay there. Hours, maybe. I can't move. Can't think. It's like I'm not even real anymore. Just this... this hollow shell of pain.
Therapist: What thoughts are going through your mind?
Client: That I'm not worthy of love. That I'll never trust anyone again. That maybe... maybe I deserve this pain.
Therapist: SUDS level?
Client: It's... it's starting to come down. Maybe a 6 now.
Therapist: That's good. You're processing this well.

Client: I finally get up. The apartment feels so empty. I go to our... his room. His closet is half empty. It hits me all over again. I collapse on the bed, surrounded by his scent. I feel so alone, so abandoned.
Therapist: How does your body feel now?
Client: Exhausted. Drained. Like I've been hit by a truck. My eyes hurt from crying. My throat is raw.
Therapist: And your SUDS?
Client: It's... it's down to a 5 now. I feel... I don't know. Sad, but... calmer?
Therapist: That's normal. You're doing great. Let's start to wrap up. Take a deep breath.
Client: *takes a deep breath* Okay. I'm... I'm back in the room with you now.
Therapist: How do you feel?
Client: Drained, but... okay. Like I've survived something.
Therapist: You have. You did really well today.
